messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 48 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Enhancing Semantic Communication with Deep Generative Models – An ICASSP Special Session Overview

Paper Abstract: Abstract Semantic communication is poised to play a pivotal role in shaping the landscape of future AI-driven communication systems. Its challenge of extracting semantic information from the original complex content and regenerating semantically consistent data at the receiver, possibly being robust to channel corruptions, can be addressed with deep generative models. This ICASSP special session overview paper discloses the semantic communication challenges from the machine learning perspective and unveils how deep generative models will significantly enhance semantic communication frameworks in dealing with real-world complex data, extracting and exploiting semantic information, and being robust to channel corruptions. Alongside establishing this emerging field, this paper charts novel research pathways for the next generative semantic communication frameworks.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 48 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 48"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Semantic communications: Principles and challenges",
        "Semantic communications based on adaptive generative models and information bottleneck",
        "Communication beyond transmitting bits: Semantics-guided source and channel coding",
        "Deep learning-based image semantic coding for semantic communications",
        "Semantic-preserving image compression",
        "Wireless semantic communications for video conferencing",
        "Wireless deep speech semantic transmission",
        "Semantic-preserved communication system for highly efficient speech transmission",
        "Semantic communications for speech signals",
        "Deep learning enabled semantic communications with speech recognition and synthesis",
        "Semantic-aware transmission for robust point cloud classification",
        "Enabling the wireless metaverse via semantic multiverse communication",
        "Semantic-aware digital twin for metaverse: A comprehensive review",
        "Generative adversarial nets",
        "SAN: Inducing metrizability of GAN with discriminative normalized linear layer",
        "Generative model based highly efficient semantic communication approach for image transmission",
        "Generative joint source-channel coding for semantic image transmission",
        "Auto-encoding variational Bayes",
        "SQ-VAE: Variational Bayes on discrete representation with self-annealed stochastic quantization",
        "VQ-VAE Empowered Wireless Communication for Joint Source-Channel Coding and Beyond",
        "VAE for joint source-channel coding of distributed gaussian sources over AWGN MAC",
        "A variational auto-encoder approach for image transmission in wireless channel",
        "Denoising diffusion probabilistic models",
        "FP-Diffusion: Improving score-based diffusion models by enforcing the underlying score fokker-planck equation",
        "Generative semantic communication: Diffusion models beyond bit recovery",
        "Energy-efficient downlink semantic generative communication with text-to-image generators",
        "Recent contributions to the mathematical theory of communication",
        "A mathematical theory of communication",
        "6G networks: Beyond Shannon towards semantic and goal-oriented communications",
        "High-resolution image synthesis with latent diffusion models",
        "Photorealistic text-to-image diffusion models with deep language understanding",
        "Hierarchical diffusion models for singing voice neural vocoder",
        "Text-to-audio generation using instruction-tuned LLM and latent diffusion model",
        "Generative models for 3d point clouds",
        "A 3D generative model for structure-based drug design",
        "CogVideo: Large-scale pretraining for text-to-video generation via transformers",
        "Make-A-Video: Text-to-video generation without text-video data",
        "AC-VAE: Learning semantic representation with VAE for adaptive clustering",
        "Linear semantics in generative adversarial networks",
        "Extracting semantic knowledge from gans with unsupervised learning",
        "Diffusion models already have a semantic latent space",
        "Label-efficient semantic segmentation with diffusion models",
        "Semantic image synthesis via diffusion models",
        "Conventional and contemporary approaches used in text to speech synthesis: a review",
        "YOLO-based semantic communication with generative ai-aided resource allocation for digital twins construction",
        "Quaternion generative adversarial networks",
        "PHNNs: Lightweight neural networks via parameterized hypercomplex convolutions",
        "Generative AI in mobile networks: a survey"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 48 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Enhancing Semantic Communication with Deep Generative Models – An ICASSP Special Session Overview, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
